review.title: Learning the Semantics of Manipulation Action
review.abstract: In this paper we present a formal computational framework for modeling manipulation actions. The introduced formalism leads to semantics of manipulation action and has applications to both observing and understanding human manipulation actions as well as executing them with a robotic mechanism (e.g. a humanoid robot). It is based on a Combinatory Categorial Grammar. The goal of the introduced framework is to: (1) represent manipulation actions with both syntax and semantic parts, where the semantic part employs $\lambda$-calculus; (2) enable a probabilistic semantic parsing schema to learn the $\lambda$-calculus representation of manipulation action from an annotated action corpus of videos; (3) use (1) and (2) to develop a system that visually observes manipulation actions and understands their meaning while it can reason beyond observations using propositional logic and axiom schemata. The experiments conducted on a public available large manipulation action dataset validate the theoretical framework and our implementation.

sections.heading: 3 A CCG Framework for Manipulation Actions
sections.text: Before we delve into the semantic parsing of manipulation actions, a brief introduction to the framework of combinatorial category grammar in linguistics is necessary. We will introduce only related concepts and formalisms. For a complete background reading, we refer readers to (Steedman, 2000). We will first give a brief introduction to CCG and then introduce a basic combinator, i.e. functional application. Examples follow the introduction to show how the combinator is used to parse actions.

As several possible syntactic and semantic representations can be assigned to an action, we use the probability model to assign weights to these representations.

sections.heading: 5.1 Manipulation Action (MANIAC) Dataset
sections.text: (Aksoy et al., 2014) provides a manipulation dataset with 8 different manipulation actions (cutting, cutting, stirring, placing, removing, hiding, revealing and pushing), each consisting of 15 different versions performed by 5 different human actors 1. A total of 30 different objects are manipulated in all demonstrations, all of which were recorded with the Microsoft Kinect sensor and serve as training data. The MANIAC dataset contains a further 20 long and complex concatenated manipulation sequences (e.g. "making a sandwich"), consisting of a total of 103 different versions of these 8 manipulation tasks performed in different sequences with novel objects under different circumstances. sections.text: Using decomposition technology from (Aksoy et al., 2014; Aksoy and Wo � rgo � tter, 2015), the reported system is able to detect a sequence of action triplets in the form of (Subject Action Patient) from each of the test sequences in MANIAC datasets. In short, the representation of the event chain (Aksoy et al., 2011) of the observed long manipulation activity is initially scanned to estimate the main manipulator, i.e. the hand, and manipulated objects, e.g. knives, in the scene without the use of visual feature-based object recognition methods. Based solely on the interactions between the hand and manipulated objects in the scene, the event chain is divided into chunks. These chunks are further fragmented into subunits to detect parallel action streams. Each parsed semantic event chain (SEC) chunk is then compared with the SEC model in the library of models to decide whether the SEC sample belongs to the known or not.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a formal framework for modeling actions based on a combinatorial categorical grammar. (NP) An empirical study on a large action dataset confirms that our system is capable of thinking beyond mere observation and deriving "hidden" sequences of actions that improvise decent performance. (NP) Due to the limitations of current test scenarios, we have conducted experiments that take into account only a relatively small set of seed lexicon rules and logical expressions. Nevertheless, we would like to mention that the presented CCG framework can also be expanded to learn the formal logical representation of actions.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we present a formal computational framework for modeling manipulation actions. The introduced formalism leads to semantics of manipulation action and has applications to both observing and understanding human manipulation actions as well as executing them with a robotic mechanism (e.g. a humanoid robot). It is based on a Combinatory Categorial Grammar. The goal of the introduced framework is to: (1) represent manipulation actions with both syntax and semantic parts, where the semantic part employs λ-calculus; (2) enable a probabilistic semantic parsing schema to learn the λ-calculus representation of manipulation action from an annotated action corpus of videos; (3) use (1) and (2) to develop a system that visually observes manipulation actions and understands their meaning while it can reason beyond observations using propositional logic and axiom schemata. The experiments conducted on a public available large manipulation action dataset validate the theoretical framework and our implementation.
